questions.question: Within the PERFORM™ Method framework, what is the primary distinction of a 'Functional Food' compared to standard nutritive foods?
options: It contains only macronutrients required for basic survival.
It provides physiological benefits beyond basic nutrition, specifically targeting performance or recovery pathways.
It must be a synthetic supplement regulated by the FDA.
It is any food that contains more than 20 grams of protein per serving.
questions.explanation: Functional foods are defined by their ability to provide health and performance benefits—such as improved vasodilation or reduced inflammation—that exceed the value of their basic macro and micronutrient content.

questions.question: To maximize the ergogenic effects of nitrate-rich beetroot juice on vasodilation and mitochondrial efficiency, when should it be consumed?
options: Immediately (5 minutes) before the start of exercise.
2–3 hours prior to exercise to allow for the reduction of nitrate to nitrite by oral bacteria.
During the intra-workout period only.
Only before sleep to enhance overnight recovery.
questions.explanation: Peak plasma nitrite levels typically occur 2–3 hours after ingestion. This window allows time for the enterosalivary circulation process where oral bacteria convert nitrate into nitrite, eventually becoming nitric oxide.

questions.question: A 2016 meta-analysis on Montmorency tart cherry juice supplementation in athletes demonstrated a significant reduction in which recovery marker?
options: Blood glucose levels during exercise.
Muscle soreness (DOMS) and lipid peroxidation markers.
Total body water percentage.
Resting heart rate (RHR) by more than 15%.
questions.explanation: Tart cherries are rich in anthocyanins which have been clinically shown to reduce delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS) and markers of oxidative stress/lipid peroxidation in endurance and power athletes.

questions.question: The 'Gut-Muscle Axis' suggests that Short-Chain Fatty Acids (SCFAs) produced by the microbiota influence muscle metabolism by:
options: Directly converting into dietary protein in the stomach.
Decreasing the absorption of all dietary fats.
Modulating insulin sensitivity and providing an energy source for skeletal muscle.
Increasing the thickness of the intestinal mucosal lining to prevent protein loss.
questions.explanation: SCFAs like butyrate and propionate, produced from the fermentation of functional fibers, can enter systemic circulation and improve insulin sensitivity and glucose uptake in skeletal muscle cells.

questions.question: Which adaptogen is supported by clinical data showing a reduction in serum cortisol (up to 30%) and significant increases in muscle strength (1-RM bench press) in resistance-trained men?
options: Ginseng
Rhodiola Rosea
Ashwagandha (Withania somnifera)
Holy Basil
questions.explanation: Ashwagandha has robust clinical evidence supporting its role in lowering cortisol levels and enhancing power output and muscle strength when used alongside a resistance training program.

questions.question: In the context of the Omega-3 Index, what blood saturation level is considered the 'cardioprotective and performance' target for elite athletes?
options: Less than 2%
Between 4% and 6%
Greater than 8%
Exactly 15% for all athletes
questions.explanation: An Omega-3 Index (EPA+DHA in red blood cell membranes) of >8% is associated with reduced inflammation, better structural integrity of cells, and potential neuroprotective benefits in contact sports.

questions.question: What is the 'Antioxidant Paradox' discussed in Lesson 7 regarding high-dose isolated antioxidant supplementation (e.g., 1000mg Vitamin C)?
options: It makes the athlete feel more fatigued immediately.
It may blunt the necessary ROS (Reactive Oxygen Species) signaling required for mitochondrial biogenesis and training adaptations.
It increases the rate of protein breakdown in the liver.
It has no effect on the body whatsoever.
questions.explanation: While functional foods are beneficial, excessive isolated antioxidant supplements can interfere with hormesis—the process where small amounts of oxidative stress from exercise signal the body to adapt and get stronger.

questions.question: To increase the bioavailability of curcumin (the bioactive in turmeric) by up to 2,000%, it should be consumed with:
options: Large amounts of simple sugars.
Piperine (found in black pepper) and a source of dietary fat.
Cold water on an empty stomach.
High doses of Calcium carbonate.
questions.explanation: Curcumin is fat-soluble and poorly absorbed on its own. Piperine inhibits the metabolic pathway that eliminates curcumin, while fat aids in its micellar absorption in the digestive tract.

questions.question: Case Study: A marathon runner suffers from frequent Upper Respiratory Tract Infections (URTIs) during peak training. Based on Lesson 4, which functional food intervention is most appropriate?
options: Increasing intake of red meat for iron.
Daily consumption of probiotic-rich fermented foods or specific strains like Lactobacillus.
Eliminating all fiber to rest the gut.
Supplementing with high-dose caffeine.
questions.explanation: Clinical evidence suggests that probiotics can reduce the duration and incidence of URTIs in athletes by supporting the mucosal immune system, particularly during high-volume training phases.

questions.question: Which functional food strategy is best suited for an athlete looking to improve 'Time to Exhaustion' (TTE) through enhanced fatty acid oxidation and reduced perceived exertion?
options: High-glycemic white bread 30 minutes before.
Caffeine combined with L-Theanine (from Green Tea).
Large doses of sodium bicarbonate only.
Consuming only distilled water.
questions.explanation: The combination of caffeine (for fatty acid mobilization and reduced RPE) and L-Theanine (for cognitive focus without jitters), often found in functional green tea, is a validated strategy for endurance performance.
